0.name: 1Forgotten log
0.text:
At the behest of Captain Donahue, I am to record my own personal experiences here on Cosmocos.

I was first to stumble upon this strange extraterrestrial lifeform.
It seemed to be, upon first glance, perhaps a plant, or something akin to coral - something like Diploria.
But when I placed my hand upon it, even through my suit, I felt - I felt as if incredible knowledge was poured into me.
Knowledge of things vastly unfamiliar and unbelievably alien to me - but also of things familiar, things around me that others had been educated on, but I’d never had the opportunity to learn.
It was incredible, exhilarating.
Unlike anything I’ve ever experienced.

But the most exhilarating thing of all was this unusual connection I feel that I’ve fostered with this thing.
This being.
In a sense, it felt...like a person, is perhaps the best way to put it, in terms we are capable of understanding.
Like Cosmocos isn’t just a moon.
Like it’s...a huge, alien life-form, sitting here in space with its own incredible ecosystem.

Bizarre as it may be, I can say with confidence that I could feel what seemed to be a rush of emotions from Cosmocos itself.
I still feel it now, in truth.
Which sounds like insanity, doesn’t it? But it was beautiful.
Like a rush of warmth, kindness, generosity.
I really feel like Cosmocos wants to teach us things.
Like it wants to help us grow and nurture us.

The Captain has commanded that no one is to interact with this celestial brain aside from himself for our own safety.
I do feel slightly disheartened by this, as I was hoping to commune with it again.

I have so much more to say.
It’ll be difficult to record all of this knowledge I’ve been gifted with in a comprehensible format on these recorders, but I’ll do my best over the next few cycles.

Lieutenant Commander Cunningham, signing off.

1.name: 2Forgotten log
1.text:
There has been a terrible turn of events.

The whole crew is celebrating, currently, after the Captain has confirmed my mad ramblings to be based in truth.
That Cosmocos possesses incredible alien knowledge, and is willing to share it with us.
Granted - initially, I was not entirely coherent when I tried to convey my experience with the celestial brain, but...tch, I’ll hold my tongue.

He’s ordered to remove the brain and prepare for it to be taken back with us to 61-March.
But this will kill Cosmocos, I know this for certain.
Slowly, over time, atrophied, until it is a husk.
I don’t know why the Captain, having been offered the same kindness from Cosmocos, would even consider doing something like this.
It’s not right.
Perhaps he doesn’t know?
Perhaps we were not offered the same thing?
Perhaps he knows...and he doesn’t care?
He’s not a man known for his kindness, after all.

I asked that we put it to a vote.
Not a single person sided with me.

I don’t know what to do.
I don’t know what I could possibly do to dissuade the Captain that wouldn’t have me thrown in a pod set on course for a jail cell back on 61.

But I have to do something.
This isn’t what Cosmocos wants.
And I refuse to see it die like this.

Lieutenant Commander Cunningham, signing off.

2.name: 3Forgotten log
2.text:
He threatened me! That- that- heartless-

I don’t know why I ever felt compelled to try and convince that man of anything, knowing he is capable of such evil.
He is not a man reasoned with.

Cosmocos has the most beautiful terrain I’ve ever laid eyes upon.
Such gorgeous, diverse plant life.
A heart.
I really feel as though it has what the more spritual of us would call a soul.
And the Captain has a gall to suggest that Cosmocos has tricked me, somehow.

Perhaps these feelings are not my own.
Perhaps these are feelings Cosmocos has imposed upon me.

Regardless of whether these emotions are pre-disposed or not - with everyone ounce of my being, I feel certain that Cosmocos is a thinking, feeling moon.
Isn’t that incredible?
Shouldn’t that be protected?

I’m going to be the one to protect it, if no one else will.

Whatever the cost.
If I fail, at worst, they’ll send me back to March for proper proceedings.
My knowledge is too valuable.

And then I’ll make it my mission to come back.
If they succeed in doing this to Cosmocos...
I’ll see it done that it is made whole again.

Cunningham, signing off.

3.name: 4Forgotten log
3.text:
Long time no see, old friend.

You gave me a real run-around, didn’t you?
Going off the radar like that.
You teleported yourself... nearly eight-hundred-million miles away.
I didn’t even know you could do that.
You are full of wonders.

You didn’t want to hurt them, did you, friend?

You did everything you could not to kill them.
You wanted so dearly to see them learn, and grow, and help each other...

I feel it. I know, I know...

They’re still out there, though, aren’t they?
That’s them?
Lurking in the shadows.
They’re protecting you now.

I want to protect you too, if you’ll let me.
No one will ever hurt you again.

Not while I’m around.
